Interface ec.util.RandomNumberGenerator

public interface interface RandomNumberGenerator
A RandomNumberGenerator is an object which can produce various and sundry random values. This is an interface; there are several possible implementations, with different amounts of security and speed (among other qualities). This interface is loosely based on the original java.util.Random class.

nextBits(int)
Return an int containing the given number of random bits.
nextDouble()
Return a double in the range 0 inclusive to 1 exclusive, that should be evenly distributed across the entire range and should encompass all possible representable values in the range.
nextFloat()
Return a float in the range 0 inclusive to 1 exclusive, that should be evenly distributed across the entire range and should encompass all possible representable values in the range.
nextInt()
Return an int that should equally likely be every possible int.
nextLong()
Return a long that should equally likely be every possible long.

nextBits 
 public abstract int nextBits(int bits)
Return an int containing the given number of random bits. Bits must be between 0 and 32 inclusive. The results should be evenly distributed across the entire range, and all possible values should be able to result.

Parameters:
bits - the desired number of bits
Returns:
the random number
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
thrown if bits is out of the range 0..32 inclusive
nextInt 
 public abstract int nextInt()
Return an int that should equally likely be every possible int.

Returns:
the random number
nextLong 
 public abstract long nextLong()
Return a long that should equally likely be every possible long.

Returns:
the random number
nextFloat 
 public abstract float nextFloat()
Return a float in the range 0 inclusive to 1 exclusive, that should be evenly distributed across the entire range and should encompass all possible representable values in the range. {The following is stolen from JLS 1st edition, section 21.9.10.} The value is computed as if by: return (nextBits (24) / ((float) (1 << 24)));

Returns:
the random number
nextDouble 
 public abstract double nextDouble()
Return a double in the range 0 inclusive to 1 exclusive, that should be evenly distributed across the entire range and should encompass all possible representable values in the range. {The following is stolen from JLS 1st edition, section 21.9.11.} The value is computed as if by: return ((((long) nextBits (26) << 27) + nextBits (27)) / (double) (1L << 53));

Returns:
the random number
